column4: Sounds like a filesystem error on /. Boot a liveCD -> System -> Administration -> Partition Editor, right click the ubuntu partition and choose check filesystem
Yes, ext3 is recommended. ext4 isn't 100% stable in jaunty yet. It's mention in the release notes
gksu nautilus, right-click /home and choose to archive it.
Is that how I should have Done my root director for upgrading to ext4 also?  Not that I plan on doing it again.
Did the upgrade to ext4 go wrong so you had to restore from backup?
You can upgrade to ext4 without formatting ...
The upgrade to ext4 *seemed* to go fine; I guess it didn't entirely.  So you reccomend using nautilus to make an 'archive' of it, and then copy it to a seperate partition?
That would be the easiest I think. If you want to do it in a terminal, it would be: sudo tar zcvf /path/to/store/homes.tar.gz /home
Thanks.   I'll do that...  If I copy it to a seperate partition, I can tell Ubuntu to use that partition as home and not lose anything, correct?
Have you allready made a partition where you want to put /home?
Yes I have, it's just.. not partitioned or there yet.
Ok, well you can do that from the liveCD, then I'd recommend using rsync rather than cp. It will allow you to resume as well: rsync -av /home /media/disk
I thought I was using nautilus's archiving tool?     What's the rsync for? oh... and what do you mean by resume?
Well, if you want to copy /home to an external drive in order to reinstall, then copy it back, I'd recommend archiving it.
Since you want to put /home on a separate partition, copying /home to that partition, then tell the installer to use it as /home is a good option.
I plan on leaving it in the other partition So I can have a separate home partition, so i won't have to copy it back.
Sorry for the confusion, and cabrey and geirha: thanks for the help.
rsync -av should do the same as cp -a -r, but if you abort the rsync command, you can simply run the same command again, and it will continue where it left off
